comment_6: i don't see how there could be any doubt about the connection to Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. If you bothered to read the rest of the series, you would know that the idea of home is a recurring theme that Arthur becomes less attached to throughout the books as he realizes the insignificance of a home because of how it keeps a person from seeing as much of the Universe as he can in his life. The verses refer to the battles that are constantly being fought over the ownership of planets in the book and the futility of war. THe chorus is an ironic statement on the attachment a person or race feels to their world, although their "world" is just their point of view and the significance of that world could be nought if they saw it from another's point of view. As for the last verse, it refers to the fact that Arthur realizes he doesn't need to continually run from place to place, he can depend on the hospitality of others as he hitchhikes through the galaxy. Seriously, read the books and you'll get a deeper meaning of what the song is about. Don't Panic.

comment_8: The song poses the question of whether to hold an optomistic or pessimistic view of life.  This is generated through both the lyrics and melody. "Bones sinking like stones..." provides the pessimist's view that we are all subject to inevitable suffering, while "We live in a beautiful world" reveals an optomistic view.  I would classify the melody as slow and depressing (pessimistic), yet somehow it generates a feel-good response (optomistic).  Thus the question is posed.  The last line "Oh all that I know..." and the title "Don't Panic" suggest the answer is to view life with optomism. Although often ugly, one must remember life is beautiful.

I agree with a previous poster that the best adjective to describe this song is "haunting."  The title Don't Panic seems to be addressed towards someone who is freaking out over something.     The music itself is haunting because somehow the song conveys simultaneously a pessimistic and optimistic ring to it.

I say...the second best song of all time for Coldplay. I can't compliment this song enough. Out of all the songs on parachutes, it is the most individuating. It feels as if no one else could've formed those lyrics. It's so very coldplay, simple drum and acousic rythym accompannied by soem thin electric guitar picking (jonny seems to hate chords). If I had to sum up coldplay in one song...this is it.

So many of Coldplay's early songs are angsty, and complain about the horrors and problems in this world.  Don't panic, acknowledges this but adds the positive "but we live in a beautiful world". The meaning is simple. The world can be a tough and terribly place sometimes, but in the end....it's beautiful. it's worth having--and life is worth living. We call have someone to lean on. 
Come to think of it...it goes quite well with "everythings not lost".
comment_123: I just looked over some peoples replies...and I'm startled by all the pessimism (which I think is a reflection of the reviewers depressing outlook on life). To call this song sarcastic, is to surrender it to a dark fate...something I never want associated with Coldplay. Martin is not the sarcastic, pessimistic, depressing type. Considering the fact that the album ends with "everythings not lost", and the mellow yet positive nature of the album, this song is most definitely optimistic. They named the album parachutes so that they wouldn't be declared dark and depressing...and in every song Chris has been most sincere. I can't imagine the last few lines being sarcastic...it's just so not coldplay, maybe radiohead or some emo band...but not Chris. Not coldplay. Take the song for what it is. A song about a troubled world...that is ultimately beautiful.

comment_155:
I know this may not be a common interpretation of the song, but I think Chris is talking about someone contemplating suicide. 'We live in a beautiful world' - this is self-explanatory. He's trying to tell the person that this world is beautiful, thus hinting that there's no need to leave this world. 'Oh, all that I know, there's nothing here to run from. Cause, yeah, everybody here's got someone to lean on'. I think by using the phrase '..all that I know..' he's trying to submissively show the person that yes, you may have a problem, but I'm just going to tell you what I know. Then he states what he knows 'There's nothing here to run from'. THEN he finishes with a beautiful line 'Cause, yeah, everybody here's got someone to lean on'. He just says this to show the person why 'there's nothing here to run from', then I think he concurrently hints that he himself is that 'somebody' that the person can lean on. But yeah, that's just my interpretation.
But all that being said, even though I've never contemplated suicide, this songs speaks to me on so many levels. Especially when I'm down, it just reminds me that I have awesome people around me that I can 'lean on'. And this is what makes Coldplay so bloody awesome! The fact that their songs can speak to so many people, even though those aren't necessarily the people who the song was mean for - that is if my interpretation was right, lol.

comment_167:
I feel like this song is about depression.

"Bones, sinking like stones" - like into the dumps of depression
"all that we've fought for/Homes, places we've grown/All of us are done for" - despite all this work we've done in our lives, depression does us in, and makes it all seem worthless.

"We live in a beautiful world..." - an attempt at reassurance, like you know this world is beautiful, and you're trying to see it. Only sometimes do you succeed.

"We've got nothing here to run from/'Cause here, everybody here's got somebody to lean on" - Depression often leaves you with feelings of loneliness and, coupled with Anxiety, fear. The song leaves a nice reminder that there are people you can lean on.

Overall, I think this song was written for someone going through a time of fear, loneliness, and/or apathy. 

It would make sense for Hitchhiker's Guide to The Galaxy to be the foundation of the lyrics/title, with the theme of depression. Great songwriting by Chris Martin on this one
